PROFESSOR: There, OK. So let me review a lot
of where we've been.

We got a secular equation,
and the secular equation said,

OK, we have this GF matrix,
and we want a transformation that diagonalizes it.

And since this is not
a symmetric matrix,

this is not a unitary
transformation. It's a similarity
transformation. We need to find the matrix
which diagonalizes this,

and it's not going
to be one where L dagger is equal to L inverse.

OK, so this is the
condition, but we also wanted to be sure that L,
that we have a representation,

the representation,
which has no cross terms, or everything is separable.

So 2T was the product of the
mass weighted velocities.

And the transformation to the
internal coordinate velocities
is given by--

and we chose to define this as
the inverse of the G matrix.
And so that's just a definition.

And then we defined the
transformation that takes you

from S to Q, the normal
coordinates, as L. And so we want to be sure that
L is the same L as we have here.

And so now we have Q L
dagger G minus 1 L Q dot.

OK, and so from this
we get a requirement-- well, and we want 2T to be equal
to Q Q. So that requires this,

L dagger G minus 1 L to be
equal to 1, the unit matrix.

So that's one-- so this
is the secular equation. This is a consequence
of requiring

L to be the transformation
from the internal coordinates to the normal coordinates.

And the third
point of concern is

we wanted the
potential energy also to be expressed
in separable form.

And we defined the
potential energy, well, we defined the F matrix
to have this form.

And again, we use the
transformation now from S to Q.
And so we have L dagger FL Q.

And we want 2V to have
the form Q lambda Q.

And so that requires that
lambda equal L dagger FL.

So this is the solution
of the secular equation.

These are the two
consequences of defining the normal coordinates in terms
of the internal coordinates.

So we manipulate those, and
we showed that this and this

are consistent with that. Or all three of these things
are internally consistent. So we're happy, and
we then move on.

OK, so then we began dealing
with the S vector method,

and the purpose of that
is to actually work out

what the internal
displacements are, impose constraints, and work
out what the G matrix is.

And so up until
this point, we're just dealing with formal stuff. And now we're going to
begin to actually derive

the results that enable
us to do calculations.

So we define but we write the
internal displacements, St

as a sum over atoms of
little st alpha rho alpha.

So we want to find these
special vectors, which

enable us to take an
arbitrary displacement and relate it to
how that affects

the internal displacement. And we say that St alpha is a
vector that points in direction

of maximum increase in St.
And the magnitude St alpha

has a magnitude equal
to the change in St that

results when we make a
unit displacement of atom

a the optimum direction. So these are vectors that
tell the effectiveness

of displacements. If we choose displacement of
unity in the optimum direction,

we get the magnitude of
St. And so this definition

provides us with the ability
to impose constraints and to derive neat stuff.

OK, so we're going to show
how to impose constraints.

We're going to discuss
the Eckart condition, and we're going to
derive this result

that G, the matrix
elements of G, are given in terms
of the masses.
And St alpha dot St prime alpha.

And this is where
we really start to make money because,
once we can figure out

how to define these,
subject to the constraints that there's no overall
translation of the molecule

and no rotation, then we
can set up the matrix. And we're off to the races.

OK, so let me try to
show how we do this.

OK, here we, again,
write the definition.

And now, we want to
consider the constraint that there is no overall
translation of the molecule.

So we would represent
rigid translation of the molecule as this
vector 1, vector 2, all

equal to the same vector. So if all of the
atoms are translated the same amount in
the same direction,

that's the rigid translation. And that's something we want to
have zero projection on this.

We want to define internal
displacements where there is no overall displacement.

So immediately, we can write
St for this displacement

to be equal to epsilon vector
dotted into the sum over alpha

of the St alphas. And we want a rigid translation
to have no projection on this.

So that gives us
the first condition, the sum over alpha
of little st alpha
is going to be equal to 0.  That's wonderful.

And that's a vector equation,
so it's really three equations.
So if we talk about motions--

suppose we have a
molecule and we're interested in valence
angle stretch,

then this sum is going to be-- so the Sts that would go
into the valence stretch

would be only the St
for atom 1 and atom 2.

So this is an equation
then that controls only to-- that expresses only
two of these things,

and it's a wonderful way
of imposing constraints. If, on the other hand, we have
something like this, 1, 2, 3,

a bend, we would like to be
able to constrain the molecule--

build a internal displacement
for the bend where atoms 1, 2,

and 3 don't have an
overall displacement. And so it's now only
three of these things.

So we might have
a huge molecule, but by focusing on
internal displacements that

are stretches, bond stretches,
bends, or torsions, which

is pretty much everything,
one has constraints of 2, 3, or 4 of these things.

And we also know
how to build them because we know that we want to
build the internal coordinate

displacements that-- we want to choose
the St alphas that

give the maximum
change in the internal coordinate we care about.

So the first constraint
equation is this one, and it's wonderful.

Rotation is trickier.  And it's actually
a very subtle point

because how do we decide for
a polyatomic molecule what's

a vibration and
what's a rotation? We have to make-- there is-- both of these come--

when we solve the Schrodinger
equation, we clamp the nuclei.

And we define a
potential energy surface, and then we try
to describe what's

going to be the motion
on this surface. And we'd like to be able to have
a separation between vibration

and rotation, which
is analogous to what we had for diatomic
molecules, where there's no ambiguity at all.

But for a polyatomic
molecule, what is a rotation is not
a trivial thing.

You have to make a definition. And the definition--
as long as we're

dealing with infinitesimal
motions, it's not a big deal.

It's not complicated. But if one has very large
amplitude motions, like this,

how do we decide how to keep
the molecule-fixed axis--

how do we define a
molecule-fixed axis system in which rotation is minimized?

It would be a tempting
thing to say, OK,

we have a convenient criterion
for the principle access system.

defining the body-fixed
coordinate system instantaneously at every
point in the motion

so that the inertial
tensor is diagonal. This is mathematically
simple enough to do,

and that would be a unique
way of defining rotation. But the problem would
be then the inertial--

the body-fixed axis
system would be rotating in an oscillatory way
at vibrational frequencies.

And that results in Coriolis
and centrifical forces

on the atoms, which
are very large and would result in
enormous problems

in trying to describe
the energy levels with an effect of Hamiltonian.

So we don't do that. We have a different
way of defining

what we mean by the
body-fixed coordinate system. And it's one where we use what's
called the Eckart condition.

And I don't really understand
the Eckart condition as well as I'd like to because,
generally, we always talk

about small amplitudes. And for small
amplitudes, it's always possible to make an
approximation, which

is that the instantaneous
positions of the atoms are essentially the same as
the equilibrium positions.

But the whole point is
what do we really choose? But anyway, the
Eckart condition is

one where we minimize
the noninertial effects
of large amplitude motions. And where do I write this down?

OK, so when the
molecule is moving,

it's really complicated
to talk about what

is the body-fixed
coordinate system. But it's never complicated
to say, OK, at some time

we had the molecule
fixed in space, and so we have the
coordinates at equilibrium

of each of the atoms in
the laboratory frame. And that's going to be
our point of reference.

So we know at
equilibrium we have

this set of
laboratory coordinates relative to the center of mass.

And now, let's talk about a-- so here we have
the center of mass,

and here we have
atom 1 or atom alpha.

And here is a motion
perpendicular.

So this is a rotation. So St alpha is in
that direction,

and this is our
alpha equilibrium.

And so we want to
describe rotations,

and first, we want to define
what a rotation would be.

And then we want to impose a
constraint that says, OK, we're not going to rotate.

And this is really hard,
and I'm sorry if I'm a little less in
control than usual

because every time I do
this I have to learn this. And I hope I'm
helping a little bit.

So we would like to write
what the displacement is

that corresponds to a
rotation by d omega alpha.

So here we have a
displacement in this plane.

There is a rotation about
an axis perpendicular

to that plane. This is the thing
that we're describing, and that is then our
alpha equilibrium.

So it's St alpha. So this is the displacement
that the rotation

that we want to make go away. And so we define that R alpha
E cross St alpha is equal to 0.
That's the Eckart condition.
So if we choose our--

well, that's the constraint. So OK, so now we'll
move on to the G matrix.

We want to be able to find
a way of expressing the G matrix in terms of things
that we can figure out.

And we recall that we
could write the G matrix--

well, we defined the G
matrix as D D dagger, and we could also write the G
matrix as B M minus 1 B dagger.
And D was B M minus 1/2.

So this means Gtt prime is going
to be a sum Bti M minus 1 ii Bi

dagger t prime. And that's the same thing as Bt
t prime i star, but it's real.

So we have this.  So this is what an
element of the matrix

would be in terms of the
masses, which we know, and the Bs, which
we need to know.

OK, but we also had
B psi is equal to S.

So this transformation tells us
how the Cartesian displacements

are related to the internal
coordinate displacements. We are building up a
method of calculating

the internal coordinates
displacements in terms of the St alphas. And so, if this is true, well
then, sum over i of Dti psi i

is St. Now, this looks
like a power series

expansion, the first
term in the power series. Remember, the 0 in--

these are displacements,
so we don't have a 0 term. The first term is just
a derivative times

the displacement. And so, we realize that
Bti is just a partial
of St with respect to psi i.

But we also had the
definitions of St alpha.

St alpha was the gradient of
St parcel of St D psi alpha
x x plus those three terms.

So we have the same symbols
appearing here and here.

And so it is a
straightforward matter to show that St alpha dotted
St prime alpha is just Bti
B t prime i.

And so we're going to be able
to take these two things that

appear here and
use that to write G as tt prime is equal to
sum alpha 1 to n of 1

over M alpha St alpha
dot St prime alpha.

So this is a really
important result that, if we can work out the
Ss, we can work out the Gs.

Yes. AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE] answer to
your question about the Eckart. PROFESSOR: Yes. AUDIENCE: So that
equation says that

for every internal
coordinate, cumulatively all

of the interactions
between the individual, the [INAUDIBLE] displacements,
and the rotation axis

has to be 0. PROFESSOR: That's right. We can have bends,
but we have to arrange

for the bends to be such
that it's not like this. AUDIENCE: Right, but that
means for every mode,

you have that condition. It's not a cumulative
condition for all of the modes. PROFESSOR: For every--
so you choose--

let's say we're talking about-- when you say mode, I
want to be careful. AUDIENCE: Sure. PROFESSOR: For every
internal coordinate.

AUDIENCE: Internal coordinate. PROFESSOR: But we
are only interested in the specific classes
of internal coordinates,

stretches, single bond
stretches, and bends,

and torsions. AUDIENCE: But this
condition is in force for each one individually-- PROFESSOR: Yes. AUDIENCE: --not for
all of them as a whole.

PROFESSOR: That's correct. AUDIENCE: OK. PROFESSOR: So for every
internal displacement that we're
considering, and that--

AUDIENCE: Each one is
it's own Eckart condition. PROFESSOR: That's right. And the Eckart condition then
imposes constraints on either

2, 3, or 4, atoms. And so it's a little
bit counterintuitive

because you have a big molecule,
and you're doing stuff. And you're moving
individual atoms,

and you're not asking
anything about what is the result of changing--

I mean-- AUDIENCE: You're going to
move the center of mass. PROFESSOR: But
what I'm getting at is, suppose we're
considering atoms 1 and 2.

We move this. We're not interested
in how does that bond-- the change of the other
bond, how is that affected.

That comes in later. We have the F matrix,
which is expressed in terms of derivatives of
the potential with respect

to the internal coordinates. But we have a little
bit of vector analysis

where we're trying to determine
what the mass and geometry

contributions are. So it's two separate ledgers
that we're playing with.

AUDIENCE: So that
example that you brought was exactly why I asked that. In other words, if
you atoms 1 and 2,

you're going to move
the center of mass, and that is part of
the Eckart condition

for some other
individual coordinates somewhere else in the molecule. So is moving the center of mass
by changing it to a coordinate

that affects atoms
1 and 2 not going to violate the Eckart
condition for atoms 3 and 4, even though the Eckart condition
is only separately for each

of the individuals and not
collectively involved with it? PROFESSOR: I think
the answer is yes, and I have to admit
that this is--

as soon as I hear the
words Eckart condition, I admit that it's beyond me.

I really-- I say, yes, I can
talk about it, but in terms of imposing the condition,
I'm not so happy about that.

But these constraints, in terms
of the internal coordinates

here, these are
displacements of atoms. There's no mass waiting here.

And so we are requiring
that we displace without rigid translation.

AUDIENCE: The definitions of
these are out [INAUDIBLE].. That depends on the
position of center mass. PROFESSOR: Right,
so what it's saying

is that every internal
coordinate that we define, it involves no rotation
of the participating atoms

relative to the center of mass.  So we're making
displacements of the atoms

that we've specified in
the internal coordinate. And so their contribution to the
location of the center of mass

and the axis system, there is
no translation of those atoms.

There's no rotation
of those atoms. And it's neat because
there's no masses involved.

AUDIENCE: Right. PROFESSOR: It's
just displacements. And so it's a few atoms,
and it's vector analysis.

And then we bring
the masses in when we talk about the G matrix.

And so you've got to
admire this analysis, but I must say that
it's not something

that I have internalized. And you guys are going
to have to internalize it if you're ever going to use--

do anything with large
motions and molecules. OK, so we have now obtained
the equation that enables

us to write down the G matrix. And so now we have to
actually begin doing stuff.

So let's look at the various
examples of the kinds

of internal coordinates. We have to solve
the problem once for each class of
internal coordinates.

So let's start with
the easiest one. We have an internal
coordinate that's

a stretch, so atom 1, atom 2. And we know, just by
looking at this picture

that the St 1 and St 2 are going
to be in the direction parallel

to the bond. The Sts are the
motions that increase

the internal coordinate
by the maximum amount. And so St 1 is like that.

St 2 is like that. And the magnitude
of this is also--

in fact, is related
to a unit displacement in that optimum
direction, which means

that these are going
to be simply related to the unit vector.

OK, so we know that
St 1 magnitude is 1.

St 2 magnitude is also
1 because we always--

we say, OK, we're going
to take displacement of the atom in the
optimum direction.

And by unity, if rho
1 has magnitude 1,

and it's in the
optimum direction, then St 1 is going to be just 1.

OK, and so then the
vector St 1, that

is a vector pointing
this direction.

And so that would be
unit vector e 2 1.

And that's equal to minus
the unit vector 1 2. And St 2, that's a unit
vector e 1 2 or minus e 2 1.

OK, so St for the
set of displacements

that corresponds to a
valence bond stretch

is just going to be equal to e
2 1 dotted into rho 1 minus rho

2. This is a displacement of
atom 1 by unity to the left.

This is the displacement of
atom 2 by unity to the right. And so that's how we define
an internal coordinate.

And then we have to ask, are
the constraints satisfied? So St alpha, sum over
alpha, has to be equal to 0.

And you can see that it's
going to be satisfied because the two Sts are
defined as minus each other.

So that's certainly true. And then there's the
question of the rotation.

This is harder. So let's draw-- so this
is the center of mass.
Here's one. Here's two. And so this is our 1e.
This is our 2e. And this is our 1 2 e.

So R 1 2 e is just
by vector analysis.
Our 2 e minus R 1.
OK, but now-- AUDIENCE: Professor?

PROFESSOR: Yes. AUDIENCE: You drew
the center of mass somewhere else because
of this bond stretch could be happening in
the larger molecule?

PROFESSOR: Yes. Yes. AUDIENCE: OK. PROFESSOR: So you always want
to define the center of mass

somewhere other than
the two particles that you're dealing with, OK?

It could be here. AUDIENCE: Right. PROFESSOR: But OK,
so now, this thing

is in a direction
parallel to e 1 2.

And so we want to
have no rotation.

And so R 1 2 cross e 1
2 has to be equal to 0.

So what did I-- why did I write all
this stuff on the board? The constraint equation is
0 has to be equal to the sum

over alpha of R
alpha e dot St alpha.

And so we know that St alpha is
either minus e 1 2 or plus e 1

2 depending on which-- And so you end up getting that
this quantity is equal to R 2
e minus R 1 e cross e 1 2.

OK, so that's the reason. The constraint equation
was reduced to this.

And so we have a unit
vector in the 1 2 direction. We have a difference in the
two coordinates of the two.

And that's also
parallel to e 1 2, a vector product of two things
parallel to each other is 0.

And so this
imposition, this choice

of these things in this way
satisfies the two constraints.

OK, now let's try to deal
with the nightmare, which is angled bends.
So now we have three atoms.  And so here is an angle phi.

And we want to choose
our displacement vectors in a way that maximize
the change in phi.

And so clearly, one
of them is like this. And one of them is like this.

And one of them is
somewhere like that.

OK, so let's call
this 1, 3, and 2. So this is St1, St2,
and that one is St3.

OK, so when we go a unit
displacement in this direction,
we can-- and this is R 3 1. This is R 3 2.

We can calculate how
does this increase? So this is delta phi,
or it's delta phi

for this contribution. And so tangent of
delta phi is equal to--

so that's that angle. And so that's going
to be 1 over R 3 1.

But this is small
displacement, so delta phi is equal to 1 over R 3 1.

Looking at my notes,
did I do that right?

Well, not quite right. This should have been
the magnitude of St 1.

OK, and so now we've chosen
the optimum direction.

We have a relationship that
says, OK, this unit vector,

this placement in
the optimum direction changes the bend
angle by that much.

And now we have to figure
out, well, what is this-- this is a vector. We have to find out
where it's pointing.
And so how do we do that?

OK, so if we want a vector
pointing in that direction,
St1, we use--

OK, so we have a vector here,
a unit vector pointing along

here. And we have this. And we want a vector
which is in the plane

and perpendicular to this. And so how do we get the plane
of the molecule or something

that's perpendicular
to the plane? Well, we do e 3 1 plus e 3 2.

OK, that's a vector that's
perpendicular to the plane

of the molecule. And then we have
something that's perpendicular to the
plane of the molecule

and that is also perpendicular
to this direction.

And that's this. But now we have to ask, well,
what about the magnitude?

If we have a cross product
of two unit vectors,

well, if we have a cross
product of two vectors, that's going to be A, B, sine
A, B. And so we're

going to have a sine phi,
the equilibrium value here.

And so this then provides
the direction of this vector.

And so this is a
vector cross product, and we want to manipulate that
into a simpler form or a form
that we're going to use. And so e St is going to be--

and this-- you just
have to do this. e 3 1 dot e 3 2 minus e 3 1
dot e 3 1 e 3 2 over sine phi.

So that's just the rules
for a vector triple product, and what is this? Well, this one is
just cosine phi

because it's these
two unit vectors. Dot product of two vectors
is the magnitudes, both 1,

times cosine. And so this is just cosine phi. This is 1, and so we
have cos phi minus--
I'm missing something.

e 3 1 was here. So we have cosine phi e 3 1
minus e 3 2 over sine phi.

So we can work out
the magnitudes of each
of these displacement vectors. These are the easier ones. This is more complicated.

But what one does is
say, OK, we get these. And we use the constraints
to get this one.

So you don't do the
vector analysis for this. You just say, OK,
you define this by satisfying the no translation
and no rotation to get this.

So that's it. Each of the cases
is more complicated,

but you can work out, then,
what these little vectors are,

and then you use this equation
for working out the G matrix.

But now, Wilson, Decius,
and Cross and Decius

have done this all for you. And so you can look
in their appendix,

and so we're now on
page 7 of the notes, and we're also nearly done.

You consider-- so
we want a G matrix,

and the G matrix has diagonal
and off-diagonal elements. So we have two different
kinds of internal coordinates.

And we could work out all
of these S's, but instead

Wilson, Decius, and Cross have
done the necessary calculation.

So we want this
quantity, alpha 1 to-- and 1 over M alpha St
alpha cross St prime alpha.

We want-- that
doesn't look right.
Is it a cross product? AUDIENCE: No. PROFESSOR: OK.

And so then there are
diagrams in the table. And these diagrams
are fantastic.

So you have a diagram
that looks like this.

And so here's two,
and here's one.

And when you have two
circles around an atom, then that corresponds to
a diagonal stretch stretch

interaction between-- a diagonal element for the
stretch between 1 and 2.

And that's denoted in the table
by RR, meaning stretch stretch,

and 2, meaning the
number of atoms involved, that are common to
both T and t prime.

And so then you look
under that and you get what this element is.

So then there's simple bends,
and so here is a diagonal bend
bend interaction. We have one atom--

AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE] PROFESSOR: No, no, no,
that's a stretch stretch. That's an off-diagonal
stretch stretch because--

so this says we have a stretch. Here is a stretch but
one atom in common. That is denoted-- and that's
not-- in the notes, it's wrong.
G1 RR.

AUDIENCE: RRR. PROFESSOR: Right, that's
where the prime went, OK.

And then suppose we have
a diagram like that.

And this would be for
a diagonal bend bend.

So we have G3, because there's
three atoms in common, and phi

phi implying bend and bend. And so there are diagrams
and there are symbols.

And you go to the table
and you get what you want. But there's also additional
notational problems.

You find, suppose you have G2
RR, the one that you use most.

That's written as 1 over M-- it's mu 1 plus mu 2. But mu alpha is
just 1 over M alpha.

So that's a notation. You see things like C pi and
S phi, those are obvious.

Those are sine and cosine. And what other
notations do we get?
OK, and so

AUDIENCE: The distances are
also defined as the inverses. PROFESSOR: Right, so the only
way to learn how to do this

is to actually go
through and ex-- you owe me a problem, right?

There's a problem
that was due today. And we need to come
up with an example

where you will use
the notation to set up

the G matrix for a problem. And let's just use
this acetylene,

which is what is actually
diagrammed in the notes. Although, there's some
problems in the notes.
And so cis S1 HCCH.

And so I suggest that you set up
the G matrix for cis acetylene,
and we should stop now.
